Articles.Content: I stumbled across the demo last year, and was instantly hooked. Bought the full game two days later after my Mun landing. 0.23 had just come out a few days before, so that was my first version of the game.
Played the 0.13 demo for a day, then purchased 0.17...shortly before the release of 0.18.
10th January 2013 ~ v 0.18.2

Joined shortly after Kurtjmac has begun playing, so I think I joined sometime around version .13. I remember when it was free and there wasn't any persistence.

And yet strangely, I still haven't put a kerbal on a body outside of the Kerbin system. Been spending too much time with my jets.

**Edited <time datetime="2015-03-01T19:15:47Z" title="03/01/2015 07:15  PM" data-short="9 yr">March 1, 2015</time> by Noname117**

I joined at 0.18.2, around Christmas 2012. Back then I had no idea the forum even existed, so I wasn't terribly focused on the different versions, etc.

My, has it been over two years? Geez time passes quickly, and I've still never done an Eve or Tylo return mission!
I joined during the last days of 0.15, IIRC.

I joined the last day of April, 2013, because while I liked the game and the demo a lot, I couldn't resist having the Early-Adopter package (0.19) which entitles me to multiplayer, when they do add it, free of charge.

- - - Updated - - -

> 
> So it seems like the population exploded during 0.17-0.19 era. I wonder what significant event happened during that time...

For me, the early adopters pack was why I bought it, but it was also the time where the game had just had some if it's biggest, most fundamental features added.

> 
> So it seems like the population exploded during 0.17-0.19 era. I wonder what significant event happened during that time...

Or just the majority of users still active in the forums are from that time. This game has been around for so long that many of the earlier joiners may no longer check the forums to see this poll.

To put it another way, this poll is a snapshot of who's currently active in the forums, not of the number of players at a given release #.

Not even, this is a snapshot of who is currently active on the forum AND willing to answer the poll.

Wherein lies the shortcoming of polls, in that they always favor groups which are also willing to answer.
